<!-- Page 1 -->

IPF/UIP
Idiopathic

# OTHER IIPs : OVERVIEW

1.  Nonspecific Interstitial Pneumonia | NSIP
2.  Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia | COP
3.  Acute Interstitial Pneumonia | AIP
4.  Respiratory Bronchiolitis-Associated Interstitial Lung Disease and Desquamative Interstitial Pneumonia RBILD, DIP
5.  Idiopathic Lymphocytic Interstitial Pneumonia LIP
6.  Idiopathic Pleuroparenchymal Fibroelastosis PPFE

---

<!-- Page 2 -->

NSIP

*   **MC ILD pattern in CTDs => NSIP except in RA => UIP**

# INVS (NSIP) 2011 ATS / ERS (CTD) * ANA * Anti CCP * RA Factor * Myositis profile + Serum IgG for possible antigens (2020) (HP) # PFT Restrictive defect FVC & DLCO --- # CHEST IMAGING * **Cellular** (MC) * GGO predominant * B/L Lower zone peripheral | sub pleural sparing * **Mixed** * **Fibrotic** (Rare) * Honeycombing (rare form) ## PATHOLOGY * BAL : Lymphocytosis ( not a consistent finding ) * Biopsy : VATS > TBLB [ Cryobiopsy > Conventional ] * Findings : temporally uniform appearance of fibrosis & inflammation * Cellular dominated by active inflammation * NSIP infiltrates : mixture of lymphocytes & plasma cells with in alveolar septum * prominently found in peribronchiolar interstitium * Fibrotic : established fibrosis DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FACP FCCM --- Subpleural Honeycomb UIP/IPF GGO NSIP ANGELATHI KATHRI MD, DHS FIB RADI BOARD --- # Clinical course * Better prognosis than UIP * 5 yr survival 80 % * 10 yr survival 73 % * $\checkmark$ CTD NSIP > $\text{i}$ NSIP * $\checkmark$ Cellular NSIP > Fibrotic NSIP DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FAOI EDAEM --- # TREATMENT OVERVIEW ## Non Pharmacological * Avoid offending agent ( antigen / drug ) * O2 Supplementation when hypoxemia * Pul rehab * Lung transplant ## Pharmacological * Immunosuppression\* ( well studied in CTDs) * Anti fibrotics in fibrosing variant Dr Bharath kathi MD FIP FACI EDARM --- # Immunosuppression - Steroid: 1mg/kg oral prednisolone for several months (6-9 months) - (Pft or HRCT follow up for response assessment) - Rapidly progressive disease: Pulse IV steroids 750-1000mg / day for 3 days - * Vit D, Calcium bisphosphonates supplemntation -> Bone health - * CO trimox prophylaxis DR. BHARATH KATHRI MD FIP RAGI EDARM --- # Azathioprine * Inhibits purine synthesis in lymphocytes * Studied in CTD NSIP * S/E: BMD, Hepatotoxicity * Dose: 1.5 - 2mg / kg / day * Max dose: 200mg / day * Maintenance therapy after cyclophosphamide induction # MMF * b & T cell function by inhibiting purine synthesis * Well Studied in CTD NSIP * Dose 500 mg BD Titrate weekly to 1-1.5g BD DR. SWAPNIL RATHI MD DM RHEUM --- 0, -> 15 days -> 6 months **CYCLOPHOSPHAMIDE** * Used in rapidly progressive lung involvement * Best studied in Ssc - ILD * S/E : BMD , Hemorrhagic cystitis , bladder CA * In scleroderma lung study MMF had equivalent response with lesser ADR **Rituximab** * Anti CD 20 B cell depleting MAB * Role in myositis , Ssc, RA * Dose : 1 gm IV with 2 weeks spacing & later at 6 months * S/E : opportunistic infections , acute pneumonitis DR. BHARATH RATHI MD DIP KACI EDARM --- **Tacrolimus** Inhibits calcineurin & subsequent downstream of T Cell proliferation S/E : Renal toxicity DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP PACI EDARM --- # AntiFibrotics * Nintedanib * Pirfenidone Recommended in fibrotic forms DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI EDARM --- | Category | UIP / IPF | NSIP | |---|---|---| | CLINICAL PRESENTATION | >60Y, M>F, Smoker
Chronic symptoms, Clubbing
fine crepts | 40-50Y, F>M, NonSmoker
Sub acute Symptoms
fine crepts | | BIOPSY | * Plenty of Fibroblastic foci
* Heterogenous pattern of involvement | * Rare fibroblastic foci
* Temporally uniform involvement | | RADIOLOGY | BIL Lower Zone predominant
Minimal GGDs, Significant Traction BXIS & Honeycombing | BIL Lower Zone predominant
* Significant GGDs, Traction Bronchiectasis
- Rare Honeycombing | | Rx & Prognosis | * Poor Prognosis
* Antifibrotics
* Lung transplant | * Good Prognosis with Steroids + Immunosuppression | --- Dr Bharath Kanthi M.D., D.N.B., F.I.P., F.A.C.E.D.A.R.M. --- # Smoking related ILDs RBILD $\implies$ DIP DIP & RBILD may present as $\boxed{\text{continuous spectrum}}$ of disease in smokers * 40-50 yr * Male, smoker * C/F: Progressive dyspnea, dry cough, fine crepts * Underlying associations in DIP: Diesel fume, Beryllium, fire extinguish powder, RA, Ssc --- - PFT : (Restriction) FVC DLCO - Mixed pattern may be seen due to bronchiolocentric nature - DIP more restrictive with reduced DLCO - CT : RBILD Centrilobular nodules , may mimic HP GGOs seen - DIP : Peripheral GGOs + Reticular marking + small cysts with fibrosis (Rare Traction BXIS , Honeycombing) --- Peripheral GGOs Dds : * DIP * NSIP * COP * CEP * Viral pneumonia --- # Pathology Accumulation of **pigmented macrophage** (smokers macrophage : **Iron + glassy eosinophilic cytoplasm + fine granular yellow brown pigment** (tobacco component)) RBILD : **Peribronchiolar pigmented macrophage with alveolar sparring** DIP : Peribronchiolar + **alveolar pigmented macrophages** --- # Clinical course Favourable prognosis compared to IPF Progressive form in DIP Rx : Smoking cessation Steroid ( 6-9 m) : 40 -60 mg / day for 6 weeks and tapered Macrolide , steroid sparing therapies (DIP) Lung transplant --- # Organising Pneumonia (BOOP) ## Cryptogenic 1. Pneumonia like illness 2. Accumulation of granulation tissue c airway masson bodies 3. Presence of Interstitial in filtrates * **Cf:** * F = M, Non smokers > Smokers * Flu like illness : Fever, cough, dyspnea * B/l fine crepts * Features of underlying disease ## Underlying associations * Drug toxicity (Nitrofurantoin, Phenytoin, Amiodarone, Sulfasalizine) * Viral infections * Radiation * CTDs DR. DHANESH KATHI MD FIP FAGI EDARM --- PFT : Usually restrictive ( rarely obstructive ) CXR : Non specific area of consolidation CT Chest : Peripheral , patchy, peribronchovascular GGO / Consolidation ( Fleeting or migratory pattern ) Reverse Halo ( Atoll sign ) : Strong association with OP DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DIP FADI EDARM --- The atoll sign, also known as the reverse halo sign, is characterized by a central GGO surrounded by consolidation. The central GGO of the reverse halo sign corresponds to alveolar septal inflammation and cellular debris, whereas the peripheral consolidation represents organizing pneumonia within the alveolar ducts. Dds : invasive fungal infections (e.g., Mucor), Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, (lipoid pneumonia, sarcoidosis, and lepidic-predominant adenocarcinoma of the lung) --- **Image Annotations:** * CT HALO * Less white (referring to the GGO area in the top right lesion) * more white (referring to the central nodule in the top right lesion) * Reverse Halo (label for the pattern in the left lung) * Less white (highlighted yellow area in the left lung) * more white (highlighted green area in the left lung) * (Mucor) (handwritten, circled, pointing to "invasive fungal infections" in the text) **Footer:** DR. BHARATHI MATHI MD FIP FACR EDARM --- # Pathology Surgical Lung Biopsy [VATS] SLB > TBLB - Accumulation of $\underline{\text{granulation tissue}}$ in airway consisting of myofibroblast, fibroblast & $\underline{\text{connective tissue matrix}}$ : $\underline{\text{Masson bodies}}$ DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI EDARM --- Rx * BTS guidelines recommend initiating prednisone at a dose of 0.75 to 1 mg/kg per day and weaning over 6 to 12 months. * Alternative regimens include starting prednisone at a dose of 1 to 1.5 mg/kg for 3 months and then tapering or * starting methylprednisolone 0.5 to 1 g intravenously (IV) for the first 3 days followed by prednisone at 20 mg daily, then tapering based on clinical response. Other options : Macrolide , Cyclophosphamide , Azathioprine , Rituximab DR. BHARATH RATHI MD FIP FACI SOARH --- Hamman Rich Synd # ACUTE INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA / AIP Acute SOB + BIL diffuse pul infiltrates + hypoxemia => ? Idiopathic ARDS Current ATS/ERS diagnostic criteria for AIP include the following: (1) rapidly progressive clinical course (2 months) leading to respiratory failure; (2) exclusion of infectious, toxic, autoimmune, or any other known cause of ARDS; (3) diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) on biopsy specimens (4) radiologic findings consistent with ILD; and (5) absence of chronic lung disease. DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI EDARM ---

# Clinical Presentation

*   Affects patients more than 40 years old with a mean age of 50 to 55 years.
*   acute onset of fever (75%), cough (70%), and rapidly progressive dyspnea (90%) with many patients reporting the sensation of an infectious prodrome.
*   Dds:
    *   ARDS
    *   left heart failure,
    *   diffuse alveolar hemorrhage,
    *   OP,
    *   hypersensitivity pneumonitis,
    *   acute exacerbation of UIP/IPF, and DIP.

DR. BHARATH RATHI MD PIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 27 -->

*   AIP is radiographically and pathologically <mark style="background-color: red;">indistinguishable from ARDS.</mark>
*   <mark style="background-color: yellow;">Diffuse consolidation and ground-glass opacities</mark> are typically seen in the <mark style="background-color: yellow;">early exudative phase</mark>, with the dependent areas of lung being more affected.
*   In patients <mark style="background-color: yellow;">who survive the acute phase</mark> (sometime after the first week), <mark style="background-color: yellow;">findings of underlying fibrosis</mark> such as <mark style="background-color: yellow;">architectural distortion and traction bronchiectasis</mark> with or without <mark style="background-color: yellow;">honeycombing</mark> become apparent.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 28 -->



# Pathology

*   **surgical lung biopsy** is the preferred approach if tissue diagnosis is required.
*   A pathologic diagnosis of DAD demonstrates **diffuse and extensive cell death** accompanied hyaline membranes, which are histologically apparent layers of fibrin mixed with **necrotic epithelium**.  ARDS
*   As the injury progresses, it evolves into its organizing phase, which can either resolve into relatively normal lung or result in **lung fibrosis**.



## Clinical Course and Outcomes

*   The **fulminant** and often untreatable nature of AIP endows this disease with a particularly **high mortality**.

DR. BHAGAVATHI NATHI MD FIP FACR KEARM

---

<!-- Page 29 -->



## Therapy: Nonpharmacologic
*   supportive care : supplemental oxygen or mechanical ventilation, adequate sedation, nutritional support, and prevention of ICU-related complications



## Therapy: Pharmacologic
*   High/pulse-dose glucocorticoid therapy but no clinical trials assessing efficacy of this treatment.
*   Despite this lack of clear benefit, expert opinion recommends continuation of high dose steroids for several days followed by a maintenance dose of the equivalent of prednisone 60 mg/day that can be tapered over the ensuing weeks if the patient survives.
*   Use of azathioprine, cyclosporine, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine have been reported in AIP, but these agents are not recommended for routine use.
*   Transplant has been successful in patients with respiratory failure attributed to AIP.

---

<!-- Page 30 -->

LIP

*   **Idiopathic**
    *   < 20% of cases
    *   **Cf:**
        *   F > M, 5th decade
        *   slowly progressive cough and dyspnea
        *   fever, weight loss, chest pain and joint aches have been reported
        *   B/l fine crepts
        *   Features of underlying disease

*   **Underlying associations**
    *   Sjgren syndrome,
    *   Severe combined immunodeficiency and HIV,
    *   RA,
    *   Hashimoto disease,
    *   pernicious anemia,
    *   chronic active hepatitis,
    *   systemic lupus erythematosus,
    *   autoimmune hemolytic anemia,
    *   primary biliary cirrhosis,
    *   and hypogammaglobulinemia.

---

<!-- Page 31 -->

PFT: Restriction, FVC DLCO
Cystic lung disease
LCH: UPPER | Smo (handwritten)
LAM: Diffuse | F (handwritten)
LIP: Lower zone (handwritten)
HIV | GGO (handwritten)
Sjogrens (handwritten)

CXR: nonspecific findings such as bilateral reticular markings and hazy, ground-glass opacities
HRCT: Diffuse, patchy, or lower lobe predominant ground-glass opacities with reticular markings and small cysts is the pattern most commonly seen on CT in patients with HIV,
Often, a vessel appears to be associated with (or adjacent to) the wall of a cyst, thus the term "perivascular cyst."

---

<!-- Page 32 -->

Perivascular cyst
cyst
DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 33 -->

*   LIP pathology demonstrates a dense interstitial lymphoid infiltrate containing lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes, in combination with type II cell hyperplasia
*   The alveolar septa are extensively infiltrated. Lymphoid follicles with germinal centers are often seen.
*   Honeycombing and non necrotizing granulomas are sometimes detected along with intra-alveolar organization and macrophages

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI SDASM

---

<!-- Page 34 -->



## Rx

Patients are typically started on the equivalent of 1 mg/kg oral prednisone for 8 to 12 weeks, after which chest imaging and PFTs are repeated.

Those who do not respond generally discontinue therapy or are offered an alternate disease-modifying agent such as cyclosporine or azathioprine.

Management of LIP in the setting of CTD is similar to that of idiopathic LIP, but the use of immunosuppression in this population is based on stronger evidence.

Treatment of LIP in the setting of HIV usually involves initiation of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART), as in many patients this intervention will reduce symptoms and improve both radiographic disease burden and lung physiology.

---

<!-- Page 35 -->



# Idiopathic Pleuroparenchymal Fibroelastosis / PPFE

*   characterized by an upper lung zone predominant fibrotic process involving the visceral pleura and adjacent subpleural parenchyma.
*   The idiopathic form generally presents during middle age, without sex difference
*   secondary causes of PPFE include history of prior hematopoietic stem cell or lung transplantation
*   CF: dyspnea with cough, similar to other ILDs, accompanied by weight loss
*   Chest auscultation may be normal initially, with crackles once PPFE has extended beyond the upper zones.
*   Notably, due to volume loss in upper lobes, a large number of patients with PPFE develop platythorax, flattening of the chest associated with a reduced anteroposterior diameter, which can be noticed as the deepening of suprasternal notch on physical examination.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACR EDARM

---

<!-- Page 36 -->

*   Some patients have elevated biomarkers for Krebs von den Lungen 6 (KL-6) antigen and surfactant protein D (SP-D).
*   PFT: Restrictive
*   CXR : bilateral irregular pleural thickening at the apices may be apparent. The hilar structures are often pulled up as a result of upper lobe volume loss and architectural distortion.
*   CT : Dense, subpleural consolidations with associated traction bronchiectasis and architectural distortion in the bilateral upper lobes
*   The pleura is typically thickened in the areas of the subpleural fibrotic changes. A characteristic feature of PPFE is a clear delineation between areas of fibrosis and normal lung.
*   Volume loss and architectural distortion with upward retraction of the hila and cysts and bullae may also be present.

---

<!-- Page 37 -->

A
Pleura thickened
LUL
B
C

---

<!-- Page 38 -->

*   **Pathology**: subpleural, intra-alveolar fibrosis with septal elastosis and the deposition of elastic fibers with intervening collagen within the alveolar septa
*   The visceral pleura appears densely fibrotic. The subpleural space demonstrates homogeneous fibroelastosis with a sharp delineation between the involved subpleural region and normal lung parenchyma
*   Poor prognosis => When it progresses
*   There are no effective pharmacologic treatments for PPFE.
*   Prednisone in low doses may be helpful; higher doses of corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive agents (azathioprine, methotrexate) may increase infection risk.
*   Data from the INBUILD trial suggest that nintedanib may have a role for patients with non-IPF progressive fibrotic ILD

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI EDARM

---
